title: How to Eat Truffles

steps.headline: Shave truffles over pasta for a slightly garlicky flavor.
steps.description: Toss noodles with olive oil, salt and pepper, and thinly sliced truffles. Top with a mild cheese like Parmesan to add a hint of creaminess. The truffle will really stand out against the plain pasta and oil mixture.Use a truffle-specific slicer. You can find these at a kitchen store or an online retailer. Substitute butter for olive oil if you prefer. Avoid pairing truffles with marinara sauce. The flavors will compete and the truffle will get lost in the red sauce.

steps.headline: Fold truffles into scrambled eggs if you want a luxurious breakfast.
steps.description:
Cook your eggs as you usually would in a skillet. At the very end, grate your truffle on top, using a spatula to press the pieces into the eggs. Serve with a sprinkle of parsley for color.You can also top other styles, like poached or over easy eggs, with grated truffle. Truffle FAQs
Where do you buy truffles?Outside of Europe, it’s difficult to find truffles at grocery stores or farmers' markets. You’ll likely have to purchase them online or from a specialty food store. How can you tell if a truffle is ripe?Squeeze the truffle gently. If it gives a little, it’s ripe, but if it’s too mushy, it’s gone bad. You also want a truffle with a strong scent. A lack of aroma indicates an unripe mushroom. Do you need to peel truffles?Nope! You can remove the skin if you’d like but most chefs leave it on so they can use as much of the mushroom as possible. How do you clean truffles?Use a small scrub brush and running water to remove any dirt off the outside of the truffle. Never fully submerge it in water.

steps.headline: Combine grated truffles with butter for a tasty condiment.
steps.description: The fat in the butter helps preserve the truffle flavor for longer. Make your own by grating a truffle into melted butter. Stir it together and sprinkle in salt to taste. Then store the butter in the refrigerator, letting it harden before you use it.Spread the butter on a piece of toast or fry an egg in it for breakfast. Melt the butter over a tub of popcorn as a gourmet movie snack.

steps.headline: Sprinkle truffle salt on dishes if you want a budget-friendly option.
steps.description: Substitute flavorful truffle salt in place of regular sea salt on foods like popcorn, veggies, or pasta. It’s an easy way to get that earthy taste without spending a lot of money on a whole truffle. Truffle salt can also be a good alternative to heavier oil. For example, if you want the truffle flavor in macaroni and cheese but don’t want to add even more richness with oil, use salt instead.

steps.headline: Incorporate truffle honey for a super decadent dessert.
steps.description: Not only are truffles delicious with dinner, they can also add extra depth to your sweets. Use truffle honey in place of regular honey in any baked goods, or drizzle it over cakes or pastries.Truffle honey also pairs well with savory foods. For example, smear it onto a goat cheese crostini for the perfect sweet and salty bite. Buy truffle honey at a gourmet food store or make your own. Place truffle shavings in a jar along with honey and let it sit in the pantry for 1 week to infuse the flavors.

steps.headline: Shave off 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of small truffle pieces.
steps.description: Use a truffle slicer or a very thin mandolin to create your shavings. Smaller pieces will diffuse into the oil better.You can also substitute ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of dried truffles or 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of brined truffles for the shavings. If you use brined truffles, drain them completely first.

steps.headline: Combine the truffle shavings and 1 cup (240 ml) of olive oil in a jar.
steps.description: Pour the oil into the jar, then sprinkle in the shavings. Secure the lid on the jar and shake it vigorously to distribute the truffle pieces throughout the oil.An airtight plastic container will work if you don’t have a glass jar. Extra-virgin olive oil will provide the best flavor for your truffle oil.

steps.headline: Place the jar in a cool, dark place for 1 week, shaking it daily.
steps.description:
Before you use your oil, let it sit for 1 week so the truffle flavor permeates the oil. Shake it at least once every day to prevent the truffle shavings from just sitting at the bottom of the jar.A good spot for your oil during the first week is in the pantry or a cupboard that’s far away from a heat source, like the stove. Using your oil before the week is up will result in a weaker, less flavorful taste. How to Use Your Truffle Oil
Toss it with greens as a substitute for salad dressing. Drizzle it on white pizza. Sprinkle truffle oil over cooked meat or veggies before serving. Use it on crispy French fries or potato chips. Add a touch of truffle oil to a pot of soup. Mix it into macaroni and cheese or risotto.

steps.headline: Store the oil in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks after the first week.
steps.description: Once you open the jar or once the the first week is up, move the oil to the fridge to keep it fresh for longer. Make sure to seal the lid tightly after each use.Never leave an open jar of oil unrefrigerated or keep it for longer than 2 weeks. This could lead to botulism, a type of food poisoning that’s most common in preserved foods and can be fatal.

steps.headline: Wrap the truffle loosely in a towel.
steps.description: This absorbs any excess moisture so the truffle doesn’t rot. You can use a cloth towel or a paper towel.Replace the towel every day with a new, fresh one. Blotting paper works as a substitute for a towel.

steps.headline: Place the wrapped truffle inside a paper bag or a container with holes.
steps.description:
Don’t seal the mushroom in an airtight container. It’s important that air can circulate around the truffle to prevent moisture from getting trapped inside. A resealable bag can be used in place of the paper bag. Leave it partially open to allow for evaporation. Alternative Truffle Storage Methods
With rice:Nestle fresh truffles in a container full of rice. Set it in the fridge for up to 3 days. The rice soaks up moisture off of the truffle so it doesn’t go bad. With eggs:Place truffles in a large container with fresh eggs. Not only will your truffle stay fresh, but after 2 to 3 days, the eggs will be infused with the flavor and perfect for scrambling.

steps.headline: Keep the truffle in the fridge for no more than 3 days.
steps.description: The best spot for truffles is on the top shelf or in the door, which are 2 of the warmest sections of the refrigerator. Throw the truffle away after 3 days or if you notice any moldy spots.Truffles lose their flavor and freshness very quickly, so only buy the amount you’ll be able to use within a couple of days.

steps.headline: Freeze the truffle for up to 3 months if you want it to last longer.
steps.description: Wrap the truffles in aluminum foil and place them in a freezer-safe container or resealable freezer bag. If you use a bag, make sure to remove any excess air before sealing it shut.Be aware that frozen truffles will lose some of their aroma and flavor. Truffle butter freezes very well, too.
